captions.text:
Hey, don&#39;t take this the wrong way, Rebellion 
Developments, but why the fuck are you still here?

You&#39;ve been around since 199-fucking-1. In a 
world where the developers of fucking Hi-Fi Rush

and Shadow of Mordor are getting shut down, why is 
the developer of NeverDead, The Mummy tie-in game

for PlayStation 1, and about 15 million Sniper 
Elite games the only one with this kind of staying

power? Those exploding, slow-motion Nazi bollocks 
must be carrying a lot of weight. Maybe a midrange

developer can either make good games or be really 
savvy at business but never both. Probably because

making good games requires a soul. The kind of 
soul that, upon concocting the notion &quot;Boy, people

seem to like Fallout and STALKER games a lot; 
let&#39;s knock off a half-arsed version of that and

set it in fucking Lancashire of all places&quot; might 
have immediately followed up that thought with

something like, &quot;No, actually, let&#39;s not do that; 
it&#39;s a stupid fucking idea. No one wants to creep

around a nuclear disaster exclusion zone in a flat 
cap and braces, bopping outlaws on the head with

a black pudding.&quot; &quot;Sorry, Yahtz, quick question: 
What was the RIGHT way we could&#39;ve taken this?&quot;

I&#39;m talking about Atomfall, if that wasn&#39;t 
clear, Rebellion&#39;s new first-person action

stealth open-world RPG thingummy bumcake set in 
a retro-futurist northern England where exactly

the same thing that happened in STALKER appears to 
have happened—a disaster at a nuclear power plant

has spread anomalies across the countryside, 
the government walled the whole area off,

and we&#39;re some random passing milkman or chartered 
accountant who woke up in the exclusion zone with

no adequate explanation for how we got there 
except that it was necessary for a video game

to happen. The goal is simple: get the fuck out 
and get home before the missus gives us hell for

forgetting to tape Coronation Street, and the 
only way to do that is to learn the mystery at

the heart of the anomalies and pick a faction to 
side with. And of course, it&#39;s gonna be either

the fascists or the nutters. Even if that wasn&#39;t 
the standard model for RPG faction dichotomies,

it&#39;s fucking northern England; fascists and 
nutters are the only people who live there. So,

either appease the evil military group who 
keep muttering about oppressing the civvies in

Welsh accents or the redoubtable tree-hugging 
druid faction with bows and arrows who keep

muttering about hearing voices in the soil 
in the exact same identical Welsh accents.

First impressions of Atomballs weren&#39;t great; it 
seems to be lacking personality. It&#39;s not lacking

NPCs—can&#39;t escape the motherfuckers—there just 
aren&#39;t many personalities to go &#39;round. You go to

the one still functioning village, and there&#39;ll 
just be queues of bleary-eyed, nondescript,

earth-tone-wearing townspeople arranged around the 
place, broken up by the odd soldier talking about

how the next civvie that gives them lip, they&#39;re 
going to top the bastard. The number of times I

heard that one specific bark, I assumed I&#39;d be 
ankle-deep in topped bastards by the end of the

first hour. The core gameplay loop consists of 
roaming the countryside trying to avoid hostiles,

and that&#39;s not great either, largely because 
the stealth sucks. Enemies spot you instantly,

even if you&#39;re just peaking out from behind a 
wall, unless of course you&#39;re immersed in the one,

highly specific kind of vegetation that hides you. 
So you can be in the middle of dense gorse bushes

and still be spotted quicker than a naked pervert 
in a children&#39;s playground with a police siren

light taped to the end of their energetically 
windmilling penis, or go completely unnoticed

because you&#39;re half-crouching in a patch of grass 
that just about comes up to your fucking knees.

And the combat&#39;s not that exciting either &#39;cause 
both you and the enemy are stuck with shitty,

generic shotguns and rifles that have to be 
reloaded between every shot, so it&#39;s like

playing a game of Battleship with someone on 
the far side of a noisy cafeteria. Fortunately,

it&#39;s also possible to avoid conflict in the 
overworld because enemies are courteous enough to

give verbal warnings if you encroach upon their 
boundaries and will deaggro if you back off,

but if we&#39;re supposed to avoid combat, and 
the stealth sucks, and you can&#39;t talk to

the dudes either or offer them flowers, what 
does that leave for primary gameplay loops?

Nature hikes? My opinion on the game improved 
when I got to the underground tech bunker that

was the game&#39;s central hub and there was a machine 
that was all like, &quot;Feed me four magic batteries.

I don&#39;t care where you get them; all the factions 
have at least one, and I&#39;ll unlock more rooms for

each one you find.&quot; And I was like, &quot;Geez, 
you could buy me a drink first, tech bunker

machine thing,&quot; but then I thought about it and 
went, &quot;Ooh, actually, a single, understandable

goal hanging over most of the game that drives 
exploration, that&#39;s pretty good game design.&quot;

But my feelings graduated from &quot;Ooh&quot; to &quot;Ooh, me 
likey&quot; when I realized Atomfall has no objective

markers. Like, at all. And having been conditioned 
for years by games that stick two fingers up your

nose and lead you around like a mischievous horse, 
it&#39;s kind of sad that a game can be refreshing and

interesting just by asking you to pay attention 
and think about stuff. And more often than not,

it rewarded my thinking. I&#39;m searching for a 
specific quest item and have to think things like,

&quot;Well, it&#39;s probably in that important-looking 
room that all the guards are worried about&quot; and

hey, there it was. Or a questgiver directs me 
to check on strange happenings at the village

dildo shop and I think, &quot;Well, logically, 
it&#39;s probably opposite the lubricant farm,&quot;

and that&#39;s how I find it. So I was liking the 
game around the midpoint. It&#39;s almost like when

a game forces you to engage with its world and 
story, then it becomes more. Engaging. &quot;Gosh,

thanks for the searing insight, Yahtz; I&#39;m gonna 
fucking embroider that one.&quot; Oh, shut up. Sadly,

Atomfall failed to stick the landing, 
and I went off it again by the end. So,

here comes the spoiler warning. SPOILER 
WARNING. SPOILER WARNING. HERE COME ALL

THE SPOILS. IF YOU&#39;D RATHER NOT HEAR THE 
SPOILERS, THEN PLEASE KICK ME IN THE BOILS.

After unlocking the hub, you pass through a final 
area full of those very annoying-to-fight mutant

enemies who drain all your health and give you a 
status ailment just from going jazz hands at you,

and then you finally reach the center of the 
anomalies to learn the truth behind it all. And

it is... a big, glowing space rock. At which 
point we put our hands on our hips, go, &quot;Yep,

figured it&#39;d be something like that,&quot; then bugger 
off home. Well, it depends who you&#39;re sucking up

to. Some factions ask you to destroy it, some ask 
you to take a sample, some say destroy it AND take

a sample, not in that order, obviously, but it 
just changes what levers you have to pull. And

that&#39;s it. No boss fights besides some generic 
enemies to avoid; no last-minute twists where

it turns out the meteor was your mum the whole 
time; just be off with you now. Guess this is

one of those &quot;journey over the destination&quot; 
situations, since the &quot;destination&quot; is just a

slideshow and voiceover before the credits that 
gives us a very unsatisfying summary of what

happened next and tries to go all Psycho Mantis on 
us and analyze our playstyle. Not very well. &quot;Ooh,

you talked to people a lot.&quot; Well, yeah, it&#39;s an 
RPG. Where you have to listen to what people say

to know where to go. What else could I have 
done? Stick black puddings in their gobs?
